text: The Triton has been renovated and relaunched at the Heritance Ahungalla (May 2006). Under the management of Aitken Spence, a major Sri Lanken hotel group, they have attempted to move away from their previous 'all inclusive' package approach to become 'Sri Lanka's first 6 star hotel'. There was also a small libary, well stocked with books for beach reading. However the biggest drawback is the size of the bedrooms. In comparison to other Sri Lankan top end hotels - such as the Galle Lighthouse Hotel or Dambulla Kandalama - the rooms and bathrooms (no bath provided) are very small. Although nicely decorated they lack a feeling of space and light. Plus the layout of the hotel means that many rooms look (indirectly) into other rooms. Staff vary from excellent (thoughtful and friendly) to down right annoying in their continual expectation of tips. The better staff including the restaurant staff were good, but lifeguards and one room boy were very pushy. Plus the internet access is ridiculously expensive ($US15 hour - over 4 times higher than anywhere else we stayed). The beach is long and undeveloped. The two pools are spacious, with plenty of deckchairs (however there were only 15 - 30 people there at the time). All in all a reasonalbly good hotel, but they have some way to go to meet the standards they have set for themselves. I was a bit disappointed and would, if I had my time again, had chosen to stay in longer Galle in preference to moving along the coast.

Overall: despite all this, we had a great holiday, but that was down to my husband and I laughing about it all and making the most of it. text: My wife and I stayed here for three weeks and overall found it to be a comfortable and very friendly hotel. This is branded as a five star hotel, but in our experience, these star ratings are pretty meaningless and we have found that nearly everywhere we have been in the world. If you are influenced by star ratings you may be disappointed for reasons I will explain later. The public areas are expansive and the hotel looks out over a lovely beach area. The red warning flag flew every day of our stay and you would do well to take notice of this because there are strong undercurrents. But we swam nearly every day in the hotel pools both of which are large and set in the attractive hotel grounds. Our room was on the 3rd floor and a good size with all the usual fittings including tv with mostly English channels, very effective shower, balcony overlooking hotel gardens, hair dryer and a safe. One day a room attendant arrived to change the safe and after emptying, picked it up and put it on his trolley. Not so safe then! There is a well equipped gymn on the 2nd floor and there is good Wi-Fi throughout the hotel and even in the grounds it isn‚Äôt too bad. Here I have to mention what many visitors will regard as the main criticism of the hotel. The rooms are a bit dated and well used. For example, we stayed on an all inclusive basis and the food in the main restaurant is outstanding. Every day there are at least seven or eight choices of main course. text: They say first impressions are everything!! We knew we were in for a rough time as soon as we arrived. On arrival we were shown to a scruffy bar area with tatty leatherette seats which were all torn and ripped. For the third time in 6 days in Sri Lanka we were taken to a really horrid room (No. 228)!! OMG what a dump - we had paid for a king-size luxury room and what we got was a prison cell twin!! It was filthy, pokey, run down and utterly horrid. Needless to say we made a fuss and were initially told we would have to pay for an upgrade!! We were finally upgraded to a suite gratis. Unfortunately this was not much better!! The hotel is in a terrible state and is in dire need of major renovation. One of the biggest problems in this hotel is the design. This hotel is celebrated for it's design and architecture but in my opinion this is misplaced. All the bathroom walls are simply skimmed concrete which gives them a horrid dingy, dirty prison cell-like appearance. There were no curtains - just these filthy heavy shutters which moved in filthy tracks. The blinds were broken, filthy and flaking!! Pillows were stained. The remote control for the TV was held together with sticky tape, the hotel guide book was covered in sticky dried food, the chair at the desk was filthy and the mini-bar fridge was rusty and leaking water. The final straw was the insect life living in the room!! We were tired, upset and ready to leave. By this time it was very late at night and we contacted our travel agents in UK and told them we wanted to return to UK asap. We were told there was nothing that could be done until the morning. We spent a very uncomfortable night and waited to see what would happen. Well; we had obviously stirred the hornets nest!! Next morning we were contacted by the front of house manager and within minutes we were surrounded by loads of staff members apologising and promising to make things right. After a short while we were upgraded again to a genuinely luxury suite which was lovely. Clean linen, clean floors, curtains and the biggest jacuzzi I have ever seen!! Throughout the whole process all of the staff at the hotel were wonderful and helpful and charming!! We enjoyed the rest of our stay. Once this hotel has been renovated it will be fantastic, if you are looking for a stunning beach resort. The location is idyllic. The buffet restaurant is good with plenty of high quality options - western and local cuisine. Make the most of the area - hire the bikes that the hotel offer and enjoy the amazing countryside. - we spent a couple of hours cycling through the local village. What a treat!! Giant Monitor lizard by the side of the road, buffalo wandering towards us on the road, local farmers working in the paddy fields surrounded by cattle Egrets and monkeys jumping through the trees!! It was very hot but one of the highlights of our trip. A day trip to Galle was very worthwhile as were trips to the local towns. The local Turtle hatcheries are wonderful but beware the 'Spice Gardens' - rip-offs aimed squarely at parting unwary tourists from their cash!! I was genuinely shocked at the number of people putting their towels on the pool-side loungers before breakfast and then obviously spending the whole day baking and drinking beer. Bloody long way to go for skin cancer and to not experience all the amazing sights, people and wildlife this wonderful country has to offer!!

The bathroom had ample towels which were changed twice daily (bare this in mind if you like us to have a nap in the early eve before dinner to put you do not disturb sign on the door so they dont disturb you while your sleeping) complimentary toiletries -shampoo, shower gel and body lotion. Our room had a huge rain shower (room for 2 or even 3 people hehe) I noted there was also a hair dryer but can't say either of us used it. Food-Breakfast was the biggest breakfast buffet I have ever seen it was nice to be able to to sample a Sri Lankan breakfast but no fear if thats not your thing there is much more a wide range of breads, cakes and pasteries, cold meats, cheese, salad, everything for a cooked English breakfast and chefs cooking omelettes, waffles, pancakes and fresh fruit/juice theatre style. (we never felt the need to eat lunch after that lot) We ate dinner in the Mustard Coffee shop on the first night the Lobster was very nice! We drunk our way through the cocktail menu on the last night all very nice particularly their own Heritance cocktail (cant remember exact name i had hade a few by then) made with the local Arak and all the classics are also available all 800 rupees (roughly ¬£4.50) we was treated to complimentary canapes and homemade crisps as we enjoyed our drinks service at the bar and restaurant was always great. Facilities - 2 Huge Infinity pools we was lucky the hotel was not busy the only people in them most days the pool attendents were very friendly and sufficent, i noted a tennis court, volly ball net, snooker room, games room although didn't use them so not sure if they have the equipment or you need to bring your own? There internet access in the Library on the second floor it was just over ¬£1 for an hour you have to get a card from the reception. text: Heritance Ahungalle Hotel is a great retreat in Sri Lanka, but you must adjust your expectations before moving in. We had booked a de-lux room with balcony overlooking the beach and ocean - romantic, eh?Unfortunately, the hotel and consequently the room was very 'tired' and had seen better days. The hotel even suffered poorly maintained sidewalks, tennis courts, beach loungers, etc. Most was simply under maintained. Our balcony was adjacent to the rooms on either side, separated only by planters, and the view of beach and ocean obscured by a large (but beautiful) tree. It may not have been a problem anyway, as on the second day of our stay, the hotel maintenance people set up a huge beach-obscuring marquee (JAG_68056) for another wedding. They have about 20 weddings per year, so we learned. Perhaps that wasn't so bad either, but the band wars (wedding band, bar music, and local flute player) that ensued developed an impossible cacophony of loud music which made it impossible to sleep. Our 'package' was directly booked through Heritance's agent: bed and breakfast. We soon discovered there were many alternate 'packages' which ranged from full board to 'good deals' offering better accommodation for less than we paid. Check it out before 'checking in'. The food was good, especially the buffet (good value and variety) ... but the beach-hawkers were definitely a deterrent from enjoying the beach. The hotel should definitely do something about them! They were ever-present from sun up to sun down. The redeeming feature of the hotel was the always friendly and hospitable staff ... always willing to serve and support. The Guest Relations team did their very best. One last word of advice would be to insist that any Ahungalla-related transportation from Colombo Airport to the hotel take the new highway ... it seems that the drivers attempt to circumvent the highway-toll gates by taking secondary roads which are long, uncomfortable, dangerous, and nauseating. Happy travels!
